G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4.proposition: This Court has subject-matter jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 4, because the amount in controversy exceeds the jurisdictional minimum for the Superior Court, exclusive of interest and costs, and because this is a civil action over which the Superior Court has general original jurisdiction.

G.L. c. 223A, \u00a7 3(a).proposition: Personal jurisdiction over Defendant is proper because Defendant is a Massachusetts corporation and, at all relevant times, conducted continuous and systematic business activities in Middlesex County, Massachusetts, including operating the retail premises where Plaintiff was injured.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1, 2, and/or 8.proposition: Venue is proper in Middlesex County pursuant to G.L. c. 223, §§ 1, 2, and/or 8 because Defendant’s store where the incident occurred is located in Middlesex County, Defendant transacts business in Middlesex County, and the cause of action arose in Middlesex County.

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1.proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant owed Plaintiff, as a business invitee, a duty to exercise reasonable care in the ownership, operation, inspection, stocking, and maintenance of the Premises, including the shelving and merchandise, to keep the store in a reasonably safe condition and to protect her against foreseeable risks of harm.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1.support_reasoning: The provided text is a concurrence by Justice Kaplan discussing the abandonment of the common-law distinctions between licensees and invitees and critiquing the continued special treatment of trespassers. It does not articulate or apply a specific duty owed by a business occupier to a business invitee regarding ownership, operation, inspection, stocking, or maintenance of premises or shelving. While Mounsey more broadly addresses occupiers’ duties, this excerpt does not support the detailed invitee-based duty language in the proposition and in fact deemphasizes invitee/licensee classifications.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1.relevant_excerpt: "The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a ‘licensee’ rather than an ‘invitee,’ or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors."

LeBlanc v. Atlantic Bldg. & Supply Co.,.raw_text: LeBlanc v. Atlantic Bldg. & Supply Co., 323 Mass. 702, 706 (1949)
LeBlanc v. Atlantic Bldg. & Supply Co.,.proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant owed Plaintiff, as a business invitee, a duty to exercise reasonable care in the ownership, operation, inspection, stocking, and maintenance of the Premises, including the shelving and merchandise, to keep the store in a reasonably safe condition and to protect her against foreseeable risks of harm.
LeBlanc v. Atlantic Bldg. & Supply Co.,.case_name: LeBlanc v. Atlantic Building & Supply Co.
LeBlanc v. Atlantic Bldg. & Supply Co.,.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states the general rule that a landowner owes business visitors a duty to use reasonable care to keep the premises in a reasonably safe condition and to warn of non-obvious dangers known or reasonably knowable to the landowner. Although the court ultimately finds no negligence on these facts, it clearly affirms the duty owed to business invitees in terms that match the proposition about reasonable care in the ownership, operation, and maintenance of the premises. The case is therefore proper authority for the stated duty, even if it does not specifically mention shelving or merchandise.
LeBlanc v. Atlantic Bldg. & Supply Co.,.relevant_excerpt: "It is a familiar rule that a landowner owes to business visitors a duty to use reasonable care to keep the premises in a reasonably safe condition for such visitors’ use according to the invitation extended to them, or at least to warn them of dangers not obvious to the ordinary person but which are known or should be known to the landowner."

Barry v. Beverly Enters.-Mass., Inc., 41.raw_text: Barry v. Beverly Enters.-Mass., Inc., 418 Mass. 590, 592–93 (1994)
Barry v. Beverly Enters.-Mass., Inc., 41.proposition: Defendant knew or, in the exercise of reasonable care, should have known of the dangerous condition created by its method of display and storage of heavy merchandise, and had a duty to correct it or warn of it.
Barry v. Beverly Enters.-Mass., Inc., 41.support_reasoning: The case addresses a landowner’s duty to know of and remedy dangerous conditions, but its holding is that the evidence did not warrant an inference that the defendant knew or should have known of the icy condition. The court concludes the defendant had no actual or constructive knowledge and therefore no breach of duty, which is the opposite of the proposition that defendant knew or should have known of a dangerous condition created by its method of display/storage and had a duty to correct or warn. Thus, this opinion does not support that asserted proposition; it undermines it.
Barry v. Beverly Enters.-Mass., Inc., 41.relevant_excerpt: “Specifically, we hold that the evidence did not warrant an inference that the defendant knew, or in the exercise of reasonable care should have known, of the icy condition that caused the plaintiff’s fall… Thus, a defendant who did not have a reasonable opportunity to discover and remedy a hazardous condition — that is, a defendant who had no actual or constructive knowledge of the allegedly hazardous condition so that it could not reasonably remove, or warn the plaintiff of, the danger — cannot be found to have violated its duty of care.”

Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.raw_text: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc., 448 Mass. 780, 783–84 (2007)
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.proposition: This duty includes, but is not limited to, the obligations to: a. properly design, stock, and arrange merchandise in a reasonably safe manner; b. inspect the premises and merchandise displays at reasonable intervals; c. correct dangerous conditions of which the owner knows or reasonably should know; and d. provide adequate warnings where dangerous conditions cannot be made safe immediately.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.case_name: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses a store owner’s general duty to maintain premises in a reasonably safe condition and adopts the mode-of-operation approach to notice, but it does not articulate the specific, itemized duties listed in the proposition (proper design/stocking, periodic inspections, correction of known dangers, and warnings when dangers cannot be immediately made safe). Those sub-duties may be implicit in “reasonable care” and “all necessary reasonable precautions,” but the case does not spell them out in the detailed manner asserted. Thus, using this case as direct authority for that specific, four-part formulation overstates what it holds.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.relevant_excerpt: “Historically, Massachusetts has also followed the traditional approach governing premises liability. A store owner has been required to maintain its property ‘in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury to others, the seriousness of the injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk.’… [U]nder the mode of operation approach, a ‘plaintiff’s proof of a particular mode-of-operation simply substitutes for the traditional elements of a prima facie case — the existence of a dangerous condition and notice of a dangerous condition.’… [T]he owner took all necessary reasonable precautions commensurate with the risks inherent in a self-service method of operation to protect individuals from such foreseeable risks.”

Humphrey v. Twin State Gas & Elec. Co.,.raw_text: Humphrey v. Twin State Gas & Elec. Co., 100 Vt. 414, 421 (1927)
Humphrey v. Twin State Gas & Elec. Co.,.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a business owner in possession and control of premises open to the public owes its customers (business invitees) a duty of reasonable care to maintain the premises in a reasonably safe condition and to protect them from foreseeable risks of harm.
Humphrey v. Twin State Gas & Elec. Co.,.case_name: Humphrey v. Twin State Gas & Electric Co.
Humphrey v. Twin State Gas & Elec. Co.,.support_reasoning: The case is a Vermont decision about the duty owed by an electric utility to a person on the land of a third party, analyzed in terms of trespassers versus invitees of the landowner. It does not involve Massachusetts law, business premises open to the public, or the duty of a business owner to its customers. Its discussion is about whether a defendant can invoke the landowner’s immunity toward trespassers, not about the standard of care owed to business invitees on commercial premises, so it does not support the claimed Massachusetts proposition.
Humphrey v. Twin State Gas & Elec. Co.,.relevant_excerpt: “The parties disagree as to the plaintiff’s standing while he was on the Thomas land: The plaintiff says he was there by an implied license; the defendant says he was a trespasser. We do not stop to consider this question. He was not an invitee, and for the purposes of this discussion we will assume that he was a trespasser. Being such, he could recover nothing from Thomas for injuries resulting from the condition of the premises, though these existed through the latter’s carelessness. This result follows from the fact that Thomas owed him no duty to keep the premises safe for his unlawful use.”

Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.raw_text: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth., 363 Mass. 165, 167 (1973)
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.proposition: This duty includes, but is not limited to, the obligations to: a. properly design, stock, and arrange merchandise in a reasonably safe manner; b. inspect the premises and merchandise displays at reasonable intervals; c. correct dangerous conditions of which the owner knows or reasonably should know; and d. provide adequate warnings where dangerous conditions cannot be made safe immediately.
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.case_name: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.support_reasoning: The opinion articulates the general duty of a business premises owner to use due care to keep premises reasonably safe or to warn of dangers not likely to be known to patrons and of which the owner knows or should know. It does not discuss or establish specific duties to design, stock, or arrange merchandise, to inspect at reasonable intervals, or to provide warnings when conditions cannot be immediately made safe. The quoted principle is more general and concerns discovering and removing foreign substances on stairs, not the detailed, retail-merchandise-related obligations listed in the proposition.
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.relevant_excerpt: “The obligation of one who controls business premises is to use due care to keep the premises provided for the use of its patrons in a reasonably safe condition, or at least to warn them of any dangers that might arise from such use, which are not likely to be known to them, and of which the defendant knows or ought to know.”

Davidson v. Arlington Bldg. Corp., 35 Ma.raw_text: Davidson v. Arlington Bldg. Corp., 35 Mass. App. Ct. 923, 924 (1993)
Davidson v. Arlington Bldg. Corp., 35 Ma.proposition: Defendant owed Plaintiff a duty of reasonable care in the stocking, stacking, and securing of the heavy appliance boxes in its store, and a duty to protect Plaintiff from the foreseeable risk that improperly secured overhead merchandise could fall and cause injury.
Davidson v. Arlington Bldg. Corp., 35 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns indemnity for attorneys’ fees under a surety bond application and subcontract between a surety and a painting subcontractor. It does not involve premises liability, store merchandise, or any duty of care regarding stocking or securing heavy appliance boxes, nor does it discuss the foreseeability of falling merchandise causing injury. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the duty-of-care proposition asserted.
Davidson v. Arlington Bldg. Corp., 35 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “American Employers, a corporation engaged in the business of issuing surety bonds, brought an action against Howard M. Horton… seeking reimbursement for attorneys’ fees and expenses incurred in defending itself as a result of a counterclaim… Horton denied American Employers’ allegations and also claimed that American Employers had unreasonably, and not in good faith incurred the attorneys’ fees and expenses. … Nothing produced by Horton contradicts American Employers’ materials showing that it had incurred attorneys’ fees and expenses in good faith.”

Soederberg v. Concord Greene Condo. Ass\.raw_text: Soederberg v. Concord Greene Condo. Ass’n, 76 Mass. App. Ct. 333, 338–39 (2010)
Soederberg v. Concord Greene Condo. Ass\.proposition: The dangerous condition at issue—improperly secured heavy merchandise stacked at a height above customers’ heads—was not “open and obvious” to Plaintiff in a manner that would negate Defendant’s duty, and even if it had been open and obvious, Defendant still owed a duty to take reasonable steps to remedy or guard against the danger where it reasonably should anticipate that lawful visitors would encounter it.
Soederberg v. Concord Greene Condo. Ass\.case_name: Soederberg v. Concord Greene Condominium Association
Soederberg v. Concord Greene Condo. Ass\.support_reasoning: The case directly holds that the open and obvious nature of a danger does not negate a landowner’s duty to remedy certain hazards and cites Restatement (Second) of Torts § 343A comment f, recognizing a duty even where the danger is known or obvious if the owner should anticipate that invitees will encounter it. While the facts involve ice rather than stacked merchandise, the legal principle is stated in general terms and expressly applies beyond the specific context, matching both parts of the proposition (no negation of duty; duty to take reasonable steps where it is foreseeable visitors will confront the hazard).
Soederberg v. Concord Greene Condo. Ass\.relevant_excerpt: “No reported Massachusetts case has held that the obviousness of the dangers posed by the hazards of an unnatural accumulation of snow or ice negates an owner’s duty to remedy the hazard…. The Restatement recognizes that a property owner or possessor should not be relieved from remedying open and obvious dangers where he ‘can and should anticipate that the dangerous condition will cause physical harm to the invitee notwithstanding its known or obvious danger.’… we conclude that the open and obvious danger rule does not operate to negate a landowner’s duty to remedy hazardous conditions….”

Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148, 153.proposition: The dangerous condition at issue—improperly secured heavy merchandise stacked at a height above customers’ heads—was not “open and obvious” to Plaintiff in a manner that would negate Defendant’s duty, and even if it had been open and obvious, Defendant still owed a duty to take reasonable steps to remedy or guard against the danger where it reasonably should anticipate that lawful visitors would encounter it.
Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148, 153.support_reasoning: The opinion does support the second half of the proposition: it squarely holds that even where a condition is open and obvious, a landowner may still owe a duty to remedy or guard against it when the landowner can and should anticipate lawful entrants will encounter the danger. However, the first half of the proposition mischaracterizes the case’s facts and analysis: the hazard here was a trampoline next to a shallow pool, not heavy merchandise overhead, and the court did not hold that the danger was *not* open and obvious; rather, it proceeded on the premise that the jury could find it was open and obvious and explained that this did not necessarily negate all duty. Thus the case is good authority for the Restatement § 343A duty-to-remedy principle, but not for the specific contention that this kind of overhead merchandise condition was not open and obvious.
Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148, 153.relevant_excerpt: “A landowner, though, ‘is not relieved from remedying an open and obvious danger where [the landowner] “can and should anticipate that the dangerous condition will cause physical harm to the [lawful visitor] notwithstanding its known or obvious danger.”’ … Section 343A thus instructs that although a duty to warn of an open and obvious danger would be superfluous … a landowner is not relieved from remedying that danger where he knows or has reason to know that lawful entrants may not heed the warning for a variety of reasons, including their own failure to exercise reasonable care.”

Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146\u20134.proposition: Defendant’s negligence, as described above, was a direct and proximate cause of the incident on October 1, 2023 and of Plaintiff’s resulting injuries and damages.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146\u20134.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns whether the defendant’s negligence was a direct and proximate cause of the incident and plaintiff’s injuries. Jupin v. Kask addresses only duty and foreseeability at the duty stage, explicitly leaving breach and causation to the jury and reversing summary judgment solely on the existence of a duty to exercise reasonable care in storing firearms. The court does not hold that the defendant’s negligence was a proximate cause of the officer’s shooting; it merely recognizes a potential negligence claim may proceed, so it does not support the cited causation proposition.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146\u20134.relevant_excerpt: “To prevail on a negligence claim, a plaintiff must prove that the defendant owed the plaintiff a duty of reasonable care, that the defendant breached this duty, that damage resulted, and that there was a causal relation between the breach of the duty and the damage. … We generally consider the latter three questions … to be the special province of the jury. … We therefore reverse summary judgment on the negligence claim and leave to a jury the determination whether Kask exercised reasonable care.” (447 Mass. at 146–47.)

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, Plaintiff is entitled to recover compensatory damages for personal injuries proximately caused by Defendant’s negligence, including but not limited to medical expenses, lost wages and/or earning capacity, and compensation for pain and suffering and loss of enjoyment of life.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: Plaintiff’s own negligence, if any, was less than that of Defendant and, in any event, does not bar recovery under Massachusetts’ comparative negligence statute.
